critique: This executive order pertains to the appointment of postmasters in fourth-class post offices and revises the Civil Service Rules related to these appointments. It aims to streamline the appointment process and address situations where the Civil Service Commission faces difficulties in certifying a sufficient number of eligible candidates. The order also revokes several older executive orders and regulations related to the same subject matter. There is no direct impact on immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. The order seems to grant the Civil Service Commission more flexibility in filling these positions, potentially expanding executive power slightly through administrative discretion. It also centralizes the appointment process under the Civil Service Commission, indicating a move towards federal control. There is no direct impact on economic regulation. The ideological tilt is neutral as it focuses on administrative efficiency.
